results.title: Venezuela
results.brief_description: Although rich in oil, Venezuela is beset with staggering problems. Poverty is rife in its capital - Caracas - where thousands of Indians dwell in one-roomed ranchitos. At the opposite pole are the rich with virtually no middle class between the two. The region of Orinoco seems immune to improvement and overall continued development in Venezuela depends largely on increased efforts in the areas of education and economic reform.

results.title: Feathers
results.brief_description: A riotous social comedy based on a short story by acclaimed American writer, Raymond Carver. Jack and Bert, factory workers, share a strange and magical evening with their respective wives at Bert’s rural retreat. Gradually the city couple are seduced into sharing the simple pleasures and eccentricities of their friends. Rated: PG

results.title: A Pace ahead
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Norman Castle and Australian Dairy Board
results.brief_description: Research is the basis for new and improved products from the dairy industry. Experimental farms test new breeds of cattle, pastures and fodder harvesting and conservation. Shows milk production, butter making, cheese making, and the by-products of casein and malt, and considers the nearby eastern countries as a tremendous market.

results.title: Strong Woman
results.brief_description: Meg tells her story of heartbreak, isolation, depression and her eventual healing and rebuilding, of taking control and regaining her life. With Auslan signing and subtitles only.

results.title: Fire and water
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions
results.brief_description:
Roxby Downs, in South Australia and run by Western Mining (later BHP Billiton), is the world’s largest uranium mine. It also sits on sacred Aboriginal land and proposals to increase production were considered to have possibly severe implications. The population and culture of the Arabunna and Koktha people could be effected, as could environmental and ecological concerns such as local water levels and quality.

In September 1997, the music festival ‘Roxstop’ was held to prevent these developments to the mine. In amongst the protests and celebrations, activists went on a company-hosted tour of the mine to learn how Western Mining justify their position on expanding operations.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pip Starr, Bill Runting and Rockhopper Productions

results.title: Atomic footprints
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr and Pip Starr Productions
results.brief_description:
The debate surrounding the production of nuclear energy goes back to the bombing of Hiroshima at the end of World War II. Since then, the proliferation of nuclear energy and weapons has been used as a deterrant, a bolstering of military power and, in the early 2000’s, as a solution to combat global warming.

With the Prime Minister John Howard’s comments regarding not ruling out atomic power stations, this documentary considers the implications to the environment, the people living on the land, our health and our future.

results.title: Through the wire
results.brief_description: In 2002, in amongst raging protests and police reinforcements, more than 40 refugees, rendered desperate by manditory detention, escaped from Woomera Detention Centre in South Australia. Narrated by escaped refugee DJ Moopsie, with powerful music by Mark Daniel, ‘Through the wire’ captures the heightened emotions, despair and desperation of the day and takes us inside the minds of those imprisoned trying to seek a better life.

results.title: The First Wave
results.creator_credit: Liz Burke, Pip Starr, Thomas Parkinson and Liz Burke Films
results.brief_description:
The people of the Carteret Islands are about to make history. They will soon begin abandoning their small chain of islands, as rising seas make them increasingly uninhabitable. These islands are a group of coral atolls, just north of Papua New Guinea. The people will be re-locating to Bougainville, which is a move fraught with cultural and political problems. They will be the first people in the world to make such a move, but they will not be the last.

In ‘The First Wave’ we meet the Islanders for the first time and see their island home. We experience their traditional life-style and hear their hopes and fears for the future. There are differing opinions amongst the Islanders about what they want but their fear is that no-one is listening.

results.title: Every man for himself
results.creator_credit: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hiding from the Germans amongst olive trees in Greece, Arthur Bedford and his fellow soldiers were told to get out. “Every man for himself”. Not only did they manage to escape, they managed to fend off a enemy bombing attack and didn’t suffer a single casualty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
